hedline.hl2: Racism Up After 9/11, European Monitor Says

abstract.p: European Union's racism monitor Bob Purkiss warns bias against Muslims and Jews has increased in Europe since Sept 11 terrorism and subsequent escalation of Israeli-Palestinian conflict, report to European Union leaders; cites danger that racism has embedded itself; calls on union to deal with social and economic factors fueling prejudice; blames news media and politicians for fomenting racism; French National Assembly unanimously adopts bill toughening penalties against racist and anti-Semitic acts and putting greater pressure on local officials to prosecute such acts (M)

block.p: Bias against Muslims and Jews in Europe has increased since the Sept. 11 attacks last year and with the subsequent escalation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the European Union's racism monitor warned today.

''Now it seems legitimate to have anti-Muslim and anti-Semitic views on some issues,'' said the official, Bob Purkiss, chairman of the European Monitoring Center on Racism and Xenophobia, in delivering a report on racism in Europe to leaders of the 15-nation bloc who were gathered in Brussels.

Bias against Muslims and Jews in Europe has increased since the Sept. 11 attacks last year and with the subsequent escalation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the European Union's racism monitor warned today.

''Now it seems legitimate to have anti-Muslim and anti-Semitic views on some issues,'' said the official, Bob Purkiss, chairman of the European Monitoring Center on Racism and Xenophobia, in delivering a report on racism in Europe to leaders of the 15-nation bloc who were gathered in Brussels.
Citing a danger that racism had ''embedded itself'' in Europe, he called on the union to deal with the social and economic factors fueling the prejudice.
The report noted increased harassment of people who ''looked Muslim,'' particularly women wearing head scarves, and a wave of attacks on Jews and synagogues.

That assessment was echoed in Paris, where Pierre Bedier, a junior justice minister, told the National Assembly that ''recent events indicate a worrisome increase in the number of crimes inspired by anti-Semitism.''

France, which has the largest Muslim and Jewish populations of any European country, has experienced the biggest wave of anti-Semitic violence over the past year, including the burning down of one synagogue in Marseille in March and the ransacking of another just days ago in southwestern France.

Today the National Assembly unanimously adopted a bill that toughens penalties against racist and anti-Semitic acts, though the legislation requires Senate approval to become law. The bill, part of a widespread anticrime initiative by the center-right government of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin, will also put greater pressure on local officials to prosecute racist and anti-Semitic attacks.

Mr. Purkiss blamed the news media and politicians for fomenting racism with inconsistent treatment of issues related to globalization, unemployment and Islam. He said mainstream European politicians had allowed far-right populist parties to push them into a negative debate on immigration.

''People are playing politics with the immigration issue rather than dealing with the real questions that need to be addressed,'' he said, arguing for continued immigration as a spur to economic growth.
